Animal studies of use and abuse in their natural (in the wild) are far more accurate in behavior than in lab settings. There are documented examples that certain naturaly occurring use behavior, not abuse or depenence coexist with a small population of what we humans label "addiction". Omni magazine did quite an insightful article (back in the mid '80s) drawing on numerious researcher's published studies. Since then further studies in the 'field' have shown decided abilities by elephants, chimpanzees, certain birds, and rodent populations to successfully, temporarily employ such substances in mating rituals common to the individual species. Rotting fruit, fermenting in the tropical sun have delberately been sought by male elephants in heightening libido for multiple matings with the Harem. Other species have employed this rotten fruit alcohol for the very same reasons. So it seems that sex, drugs, and rock 'n roll (?) is not limited to just us humans.
Trying to draw be-all lessons of bar pressing, caged, or even in larger zoo setting animal studies is now believed to be of limited value. It's like studying incarcerated humans to draw global conclusions about all behavior: very limited value or complete misrepresentation.
So likewise relying on small generalized and fixed notions of human behavior caused by genetic variations while valid, are not a big picture cause-all either.

It's not faulty wiring, it is how evolution works. We are all experiments, there is no nice old man in a comfy chair watching out for us. Nature plays dice, if a trait or behavior works and it results in more offspring then it gets passed on. What is wrong is we have modified the environment at a pace and scale that nothing short of an asteroid could do. Cavemen did not have opioids to complicate things. That's what is different.

The seemingly warm embrace of religion telling us things we want to hear is the worst opioid we gots.

A Zen Buddhist once said: "Humans are in a primitive state of evolution, and that includes all of us. It will take thousands of years before anything we perceive and communicate can even be evaluated."

That is not true of most scientists, but it applies to the rest of us. Addictions are reliable indicators of our faulty wiring, and most of us suffer from some form of it. Gambling is one of the more interesting ones, though it's less hard on the body. Someone did an experiment with pigeons, showing they become crazed when their food pellet delivery is made erratic, and can't resist pushing the levers to the point of exhaustion. On other fronts, creatures like dolphins have become addicted to cocaine, and some monkeys smoke cigarettes constantly if given the opportunity.

Mammals are the new kids on the block and our brains are poorly wired. Unfortunately, even if humans manage to corral global warming life will go extinct in about 500 million years, due to a decaying and hotter sun.

That might not be enough time for us to wise up. If you don't believe me, watch the Fox channel.

I posted this comment on one of the early articles right after the "Bridgegate" story broke - so please indulge me if I repeat myself here -

As a resident of New York, I had no vested interest in the election, since obviously I could not cast a vote.

However - I clearly remember watching TV one day, and on came a campaign ad for Barbara Buono.

She looked right into the camers and said - "Chris Christie is running for President. - I want to be your governor."

That simple sentence - so distinct and to-the-point - went through me like a laser beam and immediately got me to sit up and pay attention.

Had I been a registered New Jersey voter, at that moment I would have risen from my comfy chair and sat at my computer to do some research on this very interesting candidate...and perhaps I should have anyway.

I saw that ad many times afterwards, and it always made me wonder why I wasn't seeing a lot more media coverage of Ms. Buono - instead of her being treated like that poor relative at your party whom you're embarrassed to introduce to your "more important" guests --

Being a liberal democrat, I always had many issues with Christie -- but the terrible manner in which a viable Democratic candidate...especially one with a twenty-year track record of proven service...says a lot about the Democratic Party Machine of New Jersey.

I don't blame Ms. Buono for not returning those calls -- she now has the free time to choose her friends..and I suspect she'd much rather talk to them.
Thank you much for exposing the emperor has no clothes. Very well put.

He has dozens of vetoes, called the State Senate a "bunch of animals", demanded that someone take a bat to 75 year old State Sen. Loretta Weinberg's head, calls Nj educators "drug mules" because they advocate for school budgets and does not tolerate reasonable discourse at town halls.
Christie is a political selfie in the extreme. His straight talk theme is smoke and mirrors. There is nothing straight about lying. Nj voters may have gotten stuck in bridge traffic but they also bought a Bridge when they voted for Christie.

Good luck to Barbara Buono and bravo.

"Curious that the sense of well-being only lasted for the first day no matter how long I took the Oxy."

That could be because you developed tolerance.

"Tolerance is defined as a state of adaptation in which exposure to a drug induces changes that result in a decrease of the drug’s effects over time."[1]

"When the time came to go off the medicine two weeks later I experienced no withdrawal at all."

You might have experienced withdrawal symptoms, but didn't realize it, if they were mild or brief. Oxycodone withdrawal symptoms can include "abdominal or stomach cramps, anxiety, fever, nausea, runny nose, sweating, tremors, or trouble sleeping."[2]

[1] Mechanisms of Opioid-Induced Tolerance and Hyperalgesia
Anna DuPen, Danny Shen, Mary Ersek
Pain Management Nursing, Vol 8, No 3 (September), 2007: pp 113-121
http://www.ucdenver.edu/academics/colleges/medicalschool/education/conti... Medicine Review 2011 Documents/Mechanisms_of_Opioid_induced_Tolerance_HO.pdf

[2] Oxycodone (Oral Route)
http://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supplements/oxycodone-oral-route/descrip...

I've taken oxycodone four or five times. Twice after very painful abdominal surgeries. I asked questions and my doctor, who knows me very well, expressed his belief that I would have no problem whatsoever with the medicine.
The first time I had an abdominal surgery I went without painkillers in the mistaken belief that they were dangerous. I was in severe pain for a month — one of the most emotionally traumatic experiences I've ever been through. After my 2nd surgery — this time with a doctor who knew me well — I took oxycodone the first day home from the hospital. I experienced what the package insert describes as an "unwarranted sense of well being" which was pleasant and relaxing and which helped me to heal. This sense of well being faded after one day, and after that I just slept a great deal and wasn't overly bothered by the pain. When the time came to go off the medicine two weeks later I experienced no withdrawal at all. The pattern was the same every other time I've taken it. One day of feeling very relaxed and pleasant, followed by restful sleep for a couple of weeks, then a day or two of tapering. For dental surgery, I took the medicine for only a couple of days, then stopped with no reaction. Curious that the sense of well-being only lasted for the first day no matter how long I took the Oxy. I wonder why it lasts for some but not for others.

Yes, and the CBO explicitly states that their analysis is not about the short term. They seem to assume that the economy will return to full employment somewhere down the road, and then voluntary withdrawal from the labor market could have some impact on total hours worked. However, if Krugman is right about secular stagnation.... then that day will never come (until a new FDR takes office, perhaps) and the lost hours will always be made up by increasing employment of other workers. Besides that, if we are going to talk about subsidies, I don't see how one leaves out of the account the tax benefits of employer-provided insurance. On another note, Krugman says the costs "must" be paid for by higher taxes or less spending on something else. Why? The country has not had a surplus since the early 19th century. It's just a matter of whether we want to add more or less to the national debt. If the figure is 0.2% of GDP, then who cares? Issue the checks and get the job done.

In a labor market that has an excess of workers, the jobs that are shunned by people who are no longer tied to company health insurance will easily be replaced. The net effect on tax collections from people otherwise not working and subsequently needing help( SNAP and unemployment insurance, etc.) could produce a net positive effect on our national budget. I see the glass as half full. In addition, happier and healthier workers as well as people who would be able to start their own businesses, would also be a plus. If the labor market were tighter I could see PK's point but not with the high unemployment we're currently experiencing.

This is an anecdote. It's not data.

I remind readers of that because it's so easy, and human, to take an anecdote as being the first falling domino leading to a landslide disaster in whatever subject area is under discussion.

In the same way that responsible parents protect their children from chowing down on a box of liquor-filled chocolates, so too will we adjust to the analogous hazards of THC-laden sweets.

And we should remember that while the young man had a frightening experience, he didn't die of alcohol poisoning.

The hazards of marijuana are tremendously overblown by the media and others. If the drug were legalized for recreational use throughout our country tomorrow, our biggest health hazards would remain smoking, alcoholism, and obesity. Adverse outcomes due to marijuana use would be a molehill next to those mountains.

I have no interest in marijuana myself, but I find it very hard to believe that anyone who went to college, or even high school, in the last 10-20 years (like the college student in this post) does not know what 4:20 means. I can't speak for people outside of my generation, but I am familiar with both public and private schools, rich kids and working class kids, and I've lived all over the country. Before today, I have never heard anyone express confusion at the meaning of "4:20." To prove the ubiquity of the phrase, just Google "420" - the first page to pop up is the Wikipedia page on "cannabis culture." Which is to say: I think this candy bar was labeled appropriately, but if people really don't know what 4:20 means (really?), then maybe it should have a clearer label. Banning pot candy like candy aspirin is overkill, I think.
